Standards.comment: The IIIF community has developed several standards for interoperable web-based image delivery.

Image Servers.comment: These servers support the IIIF Image API. Some may also have support for the Presentation API.

Image Server Shims.comment: These shims allow you to use an image server that does not currently support IIIF. If you have not implemented an image server yet, this is probably not where you want to start.

Image Tools.comment: Various tools for working with images such as cropping tools.

Presentation API Shims.comment: These shims allow you to use systems with presentation metadata (e.g. structure or sequences) that do not currently support IIIF. If you have not implemented the Presentation API yet, this is probably not where you want to start.

Content Search API.comment: Libraries and applications that support the Content Search API.

Authentication.comment: Some resources about the IIIF Authentication API.

Tutorials.comment: Tutorials for how to accomplish functionality in your applications.

Videos and Slide Decks.comment: Slide decks and presentation videos with a focus on IIIF.

Discovery.comment: Links to help you discover IIIF resources that have been shared, demonstrations of IIIF discovery and useful discovery tools.

Annotations.comment: While annotations are not specified by IIIF they are an important enabling technology.

CMS Integration.comment: Content Management Systems (CMS) modules that implement or leverage the IIIF APIs.

Newspapers.comment: These are resources that are specifically useful for working with newspapers. Many of them are outputs of the IIF Newspaper Community Group.

Community.comment: IIIF is a community-based initiative that relies on active participation, discussion, and input. To get involved and learn more, see the IIIF Community page.

list.comment: Specifies a web service that returns an image in response to a standard HTTP or HTTPS request.
Provides the information necessary to allow a rich, online viewing environment for primarily image-based objects to be presented to a human user, likely in conjunction with the IIIF Image API.
Specifies interoperability mechanism for searching within annotations.
Describes a set of workflows for guiding the user through an existing access control system.
Describes the set of related services that have been identified as useful to reference from the IIIF APIs.
List of all API annex documents and API implementation notes.
Written in Python.
High performance image server.
Written in Ruby as a Rails engine.
IIIFv2 image server written in C++.
100% open source tile server for JP2 images written in Go.
Image server written in Java.
Image server written in Java.
Ruby library for generating a static IIIF level 0 Image and Presentation API server on Amazon S3.
IIIF server written in Java supporting IIIF Image and Presentation API.
IIIF server written in go (fork of greut/iiif).
IIIF Image API 2.1 server as an AWS Serverless Application.
Convert IIIF URLs into the URLs that Djatoka requires.
Ruby gem designed to help you build shims for the IIIF Presentation API.
Makes ContentDM images available through IIIF. Python.
Flask extension to support IIIF in Python/Flask applications. See Flask-IIIF previewer demo and Flask-IIIF RESTful demo.
Rich embeddable interface.
IIIF tile support.
OpenSeadragon plugin for physical scale overlay.
OpenSeadragon plugin with utility functions.
Lightweight, extensible IIIF image viewer.
Multi-up workspace. See also Awesome Mirador list.
IIIF image viewer optimized for speed and flexibility.
IIIF WebGL / Canvas / DOM mobile-ready fast viewer powered by OpenLayers V3.
Slim and fast IIIF document viewer built with Vue.js.
A general IIIF viewer with added focus on curation and ordering of cropped IIIF images. Demo
React library to build IIIF Presentation 3 level viewing experiences including support for annotations.
High-performance, feature-packed Javascript library especially built for maps. It supports the IIIF Image API 2.1.
Java IIIF API libraries.
Python library for generating and parsing IIIF Image API URLs.
Ruby library for creating and parsing IIIF Image API URLs.
Python library providing a reference implementation of the Image API. Also includes a test server and static tile generator.
IIIF image API and Zoomify viewer for iOS, written in Swift.
A bring your own framework solution for implementing IIIF Image API 2.1 with PHP.
A fast image processing library with low memory needs. Includes an operation that can build image pyramids compatible with IIIF Image API.
Example of using Leaflet to provide IIIF cropping.
Simple image cropper.
Script to allow for cropping an image from within OpenSeadragon.
Create IIIF image regions from image files at Wikimedia Commons.
UCD's tool to crop images and manipulate via IIIF attributes; integrate with Mirador via plugin.

A demo app by the Victoria & Albert useful for the alignment of overlayed images, served by the IIIF Image API, and providing an interactive viewer for overlayed images, presented fluidly, using responsive image tags.
Website using Leaflet-IIIF Cropping and Jekyll that allow users to enter the URL of a IIIF image and get the URL for the cropped section of the image.
IIIF Presentation API client and server utility library.
Wraps Manifesto to provide viewer state and related utilities.
Ruby API for creating IIIF manifests.
Python library providing a reference implementation.
Java IIIF API libraries.
PHP library for generating IIIF manifests.
npm module for creating and manipulating IIIF manifests.
IIIF tree menu sortable by date with multi-select capability.
IIIF Presentation API 2.0+ validation library.

Documentation on IIIF-related libraries and components, from an open community of designers and developers interested in creating composable and interoperable interfaces for consuming and creating online content.
IIIF presentation API library for Swift.
Ruby gem designed to help you build shims for the IIIF Presentation API, and has samples for NYPL, Flickr, and the US National Archives.
For newspapers digitized in the National Digital Newspaper Program.
Web application for importing, viewing, updating, and exporting manifests. See a demo.
Web service for creating IIIF manifests from METS/MODS documents.
Organise your files according to a simple naming convention to generate IIIF v3 manifests.
A CLI tool that generates IIIF Presentation 2.1 Manifests from METS/MODS (produced by Kitodo).

list.ptitle: File Analyzer IIIF Manifest Generator from Existing Metadata
list.comment: Georgetown's desktop application that will generate IIIF manifest files from existing metadata files.
Rails application to create, index, and search text from page images and provide results in IIIF Content Search API format.
Python/Flask/Solr application to index IIIF manifests alongside ALTO representations and provide a IIIF Content Search API endpoint.
Manifests with accompanying images that demonstrate various IIIF authentication modes.

list.ptitle: IIIF.io : the hardest part will be saying "no".
list.comment: Blog post by Russell McOrmond considering the challenges of restricting access to Canadiana's resources.
A demo server implementation of all apsects of the IIIF Authentication specification.
Client implementation of the IIIF Authentication specification.
A simple server implementation based on Docker and Flask.
Learn about the structure of a IIIF URL through manipulating the parameters and seeing the results in a live demo.
A step-by-step walkthrough of how to implement IIIF.
Quick overview of how you might get started with implementing various IIIF standards.
Getting a IIIF image into Mirador with drag-and-drop and email.

list.ptitle: Fellow Travelers: The Canterbury Tales and IIIF
list.comment: Benjamin Albritton; includes an explanation of the use case for medieval scholars using Chaucer as an example and short section on how to make a page comparison demo in Mirador.
Introduction to IIIF (in French).
Uses IIIF as an example to explain APIs.
Demonstration of how a canvas can have a choice of images and a viewer can toggle between them.
Introduction originally presented during a workshop at the 2017 Code4Lib Conference at Los Angeles, CA.
An online workshop that covers the basics of IIIF including the Image and Presentation APIs.
A thorough introduction to the IIIF specifications and tools for using them, by Tom Crane at Digirati.
Covers Image API, Presentation API, and annotations.

list.ptitle: Suggested measures for deploying IIIF in Swiss cultural heritage institutions (White paper)
list.comment: Julien A. Raemy & René Schneider (2019).
A short guide to download digitized books from Internet Archive and rehost on your own infrastructure using IIIF with full-text search [from raffaele messuti / @atomotic].
High level overview of the Image API parameters.

list.ptitle: OA - Shared Canvas - TEI - Biblissima project
list.comment: Part of a workshop on TEI and neighboring standards including IIIF.
How IIIF can be used on small projects with limited infrastructure, presented at KeystoneDH 2016.
Rob Sanderson.

list.ptitle: Video from IIIF event at the National Gallery of Art
Video from the outreach event at the Museum of Modern Art

list.comment: From various IIIF events.

list.ptitle: An Introduction to the International Image Interoperability Framework
list.comment: Presentation introducing IIIF for new audiences as "the API for humans" - also contains videos from other IIIF presentations.
Extensive presentation introducing IIIF with numerous examples and video demos, Beijing, October 2017.
German translation of the above presentation.

list.ptitle: YouTube playlist from IIIF Göttingen Showcase
list.comment: Day of presentations geared toward relative newcomers to IIIF, covering a variety of general topics; Recorded June 24, 2019 (see full program for links to abstracts).

list.ptitle: YouTube playlist from IIIF Göttingen Lightning Talks
list.comment: Short talks (usually ~10 minutes) covering a variety of topics and new IIIF implementations; recorded June June 26, 2019 (see full program for links to abstracts).

list.ptitle: DHtech Workshop: Image Servers and IIIF
list.comment: Slides and recording from a DARIAH-DE workshop in 2018 by Robert Casties.
Repository that includes links to known IIIF presentation manifest collections.
Open-source IIIF-compliant research and discovery platform. This is the IIIF-compliant version of the platform driving [Digital Bodleian] (http://digital.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/).
Github repository for iNQUIRE.
Provides cross-library search of thousands of musical scores and manuscripts.
OCLC's IIIF Explorer is a prototype application that searches across images (all IIIF-enabled) in the CONTENTdm digital content management systems hosted by OCLC.
Europeana provides a filter to identify all IIIF-enabled resources in its collections.
Prototype discovery system for IIIF resources in Japan.
Prototype application that allows you to search across IIIF-compliant manuscripts and rare books dated before 1800.
A web browser extension to open IIIF manifest link in your favorite IIIF viewer.
Demos of using annotations for storytelling.
Crowdsourced contributions are serialised according to the Web Annotations Data Model.

list.ptitle: Annona Annotation Library: iiif-annotation viewer JavaScript library
list.comment: JavaScript library that uses custom tags and url of the annotation to load annotated image, corresponding annotations, tags, and text into HTML object or OpenSeadragon viewer with overlays.

Jekyll front end, Flask backend, equipped with Vagrant Box that provides a Mirador viewer for creating and save annotations into Jekyll site. Annotations are sharable by using GitHub pages with Jekyll front end.
Mongo-backed annotation server written in Python.
Java annotation server backed by an Apache Jena triple store, Sesame, or Solr.
Java and Postgres annotation server.
IIIF annotations JS client over IPFS.
Simple IIIF annotations mounted in a Ruby on Rails applications.
Mirador Viewer packaged as a desktop app (macos, linux) with an embedded annotation endpoint that saves annotations to a local sqlite database.
Drupal 7 module that provides an easy way to add IIIF Images to content types, and configure their display. Supports Image API versions 1.0 or 2.0.
Omeka S module that integrates UniversalViewer.
Omeka S module that implements the IIIF Image and Presentation APIs.
Omeka S module that integrates the Mirador image viewer.

IIIF Toolkit by University of Toronto Libraries is a plugin for Omeka Classic (2.3+) that integrates Mirador with a built-in annotator, a manifest generator, Simple Pages shortcodes and Exhibit Builder blocks for a rich presentation experience.
Working documents of the Interest Group for meeting minutes, and working drafts of best practices, etc.
Provides access to over 1 million newspaper pages using the IIIF Image API.
National Library of Wales' guide, which provides an explanation and examples of how IIIF applies to newspapers.

list.ptitle: Populating the Annotation Store with IIIF Annotation List
list.comment: Provides instructions on how to edit OCR text using annotations in Mirador.
Friendly fork of chronam which is a webapp for viewing National Digital Newspaper Program data from the Library of Congress.
Docker friendly setup for open-oni, which will set up and configure the Web application as well as the MySQL, Solr and RAIS Image Server.
Python program for turning National Digital Newspaper Program data into static IIIF JSON that is ready for mounting on the Web.
Cell biology annotations in a deep zoom viewer.
Drag-and-drop image tile puzzles created by Michael Appleby, Yale Center for British Art.
More drag-and-drop puzzles and a Medieval Word Maker, created by Ben Albritton, Stanford University Libraries.

A IIIF powered, Chrome extension that displays a random map from the David Rumsey Map Collection everytime you open a new tab in your browser. Built using Leaflet-IIIF and React.js. Created by Jack Reed, Stanford University Libraries.
Deep zoom into a huge (1bn x 1bn pixel) fractal image, created by Sean Martin, Applied IIIF.

A prototype "game" created for use on the British Library's crowd-sourcing arcade machine. Players have to flag up errors in the OCR transcriptions of content taken from the Qatar Digital Library. Created by Jon White and Tristan Roddis, Cogapp.
A virtual art gallery using OpenSeadragon and custom image generation, created by Stephen Fraser, Digirati. Also see full source code.
A prototype that deliberately mixes up portrait paintings. Created using Node.js by Jeff Steward, Harvard Art Museums.

A 3D environment that displays nineteenth-century trade cards from the Boston Public Library. Designed to be viewed on a mobile phone, ideally with Google Cardboard. Created using three.js by Jon White, Cogapp.

Experiment with the W3C Web Annotation Data Model. The  annotations present a sequence of stories associated with a large image. Optimised for mobile. Created by Andrew Dyton and Stephen Fraser, Digirati, for Wellcome Collection.
Image comparison using leaflet slider by Digirati.

list.ptitle: Image Comparison with a Magnifying Glass
list.comment: Image comparison using leaflet magnifying glass by Digirati.
Beautiful use of IIIF images to show X-rays of Balenciaga fashion by the Victoria & Albert Museum.
Cogapp's showcase of recent experiments in digital storytelling using IIIF.
An AppleTV application that uses IIIF to turn any room into a map room.
Award-winning digital art app that cuts and re-combines historical portraits. Based on IIIF.
Award-winning web application to create designs for smartphone cases from IIIF resources.
Getty's tool leverages IIIF to create custom patterns featuring artwork from famous art collections around the world.
